stem: The nurse is preparing to obtain an arterial blood gas (ABG) sample from the radial artery. Place the steps in the correct order.

options.text: Heparinize the syringe (if not pre-packaged) and cleanse the site.
Expel air bubbles from the syringe and place on ice.
Perform the Allen test to verify collateral circulation.
Palpate the radial pulse and insert the needle at a 45-degree angle.
Withdraw the needle and apply firm, direct pressure for 5 minutes.

rationale.correct: ABGs are high-risk due to arterial pressure. (1) Allen test is mandatory to prevent ischemia if the radial artery is damaged. (2) Prep the equipment. (3) Puncture at a steeper angle than a vein. (4) Pressure is critical for 5 mins (uninterrupted) to prevent hematoma. (5) Bubbles and heat alter the results; ice slows metabolism of the cells in the sample.
rationale.incorrect: Failing to perform the Allen test before puncture is a major safety violation.
clinicalPearls: If the client is on anticoagulants, hold pressure for at least 15 minutes instead of 5.

questionTrap.howToOvercome: Remember that air bubbles must be removed *before* the sample is capped and iced. Air will change the PaO2 and PaCO2 readings.

reviewUnits.heading: Arterial Blood Sampling
reviewUnits.body: Nurses must coordinate with the lab for immediate transport. Assessing the site for hematoma and distal circulation post-procedure is a priority.
